message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest gestational diabetes, which is caused by increased insulin resistance during pregnancy. Human placental lactogen is the hormone predominantly responsible for insulin resistance during pregnancy. The increased serum C-peptide concentration indicates increased insulin production. The polyhydramnios and large for gestational age fetus are also common complications of gestational diabetes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased serum C-peptide concentration indicates increased insulin production, which is primarily caused by human placental lactogen during pregnancy. Polyhydramnios and large for gestational age fetus are also common with high human placental lactogen levels. Estrogen and progesterone have various effects during pregnancy, but they do not cause increased insulin production. Adrenocorticotropic hormone is not typically elevated during pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased serum C-peptide concentration and polyhydramnios suggest gestational diabetes. Human placental lactogen is known to cause insulin resistance and is predominantly responsible for the observed laboratory changes in this patient. Estrogen and progesterone have minor effects on glucose metabolism, while adrenocorticotropic hormone is not involved in diabetes during pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased serum C-peptide concentration and the presence of polyhydramnios suggest gestational diabetes, which is caused by insulin resistance due to the secretion of hormones such as human placental lactogen. The other hormone options are not primarily associated with gestational diabetes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of polyhydramnios and a large for gestational age fetus suggest gestational diabetes mellitus, and the increased serum C-peptide concentration indicates increased insulin production. Among the options, only human placental lactogen (HPL) is responsible for the increased insulin resistance and increased insulin production during pregnancy. HPL acts as an antagonist to insulin and increases maternal blood glucose levels to support fetal growth.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased serum C-peptide concentration and polyhydramnios suggest gestational diabetes. Human placental lactogen is responsible for the insulin resistance seen in gestational diabetes, leading to increased serum C-peptide concentration and macrosomia in the fetus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased serum C-peptide concentration, polyhydramnios, and large for gestational age fetus suggest gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), which is associated with increased levels of human placental lactogen. The other hormones listed do not primarily affect glucose metabolism and are not associated with GDM.

We refer to PubMed Health for help. Human placental lactogen (hPL) is secreted by the placenta and is responsible for promoting fetal growth and metabolism. It may also contribute to maternal insulin resistance, leading to increased serum C-peptide levels and polyhydramnios. Estrogen and progesterone levels increase during pregnancy but are not primarily responsible for the observed changes. Adrenocorticotropic hormone does not play a significant role in pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, increased urinary frequency, polyhydramnios, and large for gestational age fetus suggest gestational diabetes. Increased serum C-peptide concentration is caused by increased insulin production, which is stimulated by human placental lactogen.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased serum C-peptide concentration, polyhydramnios, and large for gestational age fetus suggests gestational diabetes. Human placental lactogen (hPL) is predominantly responsible for the observed laboratory changes in this patient. hPL decreases maternal insulin sensitivity, increases insulin secretion, and increases insulin resistance, leading to increased serum C-peptide concentration and gestational diabetes.
